Description: High-level definition of the project's goals
Result: and core value proposition. Provides direction for all future work.

Description: The Product Owner compiles an ordered list of all desired features
High-level plan outlining which features from the backlog are targeted for a specific release. Defines a rough timeline and goal.
The team selects a chunk of work from the top of the Product Backlog to complete in the upcoming Sprint. They break it down into tasks.
A 15-minute time-boxed meeting for the Developers to synchronize work: What did I do? What will I do? Any impediments?

Result: and testing software. This is where coding
column7: and CI/CD pipelines are actively used.

Description: Developers frequently merge code changes into a shared repository. Each merge triggers an automated build and test process.
Automatically deploying every change that passes all tests to a staging/production-like environment (Deployment) or making it ready for release (Delivery).
column6: Code is always in a deployable state.

Description: An informal meeting at the end of the Sprint to inspect the Increment with stakeholders and gather feedback.
Result: Adapted Product Backlog based on feedback.

Description: A meeting for the team to inspect its own process: What went well? What could be improved? Create a plan for improvements.
Result: Actionable improvement plan for the next Sprint.

Description: Formally deploying the validated Increment from the Sprint to the production environment for users.
Interval: Per Release (can be every Sprint if CD is fully implemented).

Result: and detailing items in the Product Backlog for future Sprints.

Description: The continuous cycle of gathering feedback from users and stakeholders on released features to inform future backlog items.
column6: New User Stories and insights for the Product Backlog.

Result: and usage of the released software in the live environment.
